title: Partial-admission oath (modeh bemiktzat)
vignette: Claimant says, “You owe me 200.”  Defendant admits 100 and denies the rest.  Must he (a) swear on the balance or (b) pay the full claim?

options.text: Swear on the remainder; oath offsets the unpaid amount.
Pay the full claim; partial admission proves the debt’s truth.

title: Oath of testimony (shevuat ha-edut)
vignette: Two witnesses know testimony that will help Reuven recover money.  They swear falsely, denying knowledge.  Are they liable to bring a sin-offering or to compensate the loss?

options.text: They owe only a sin-offering – a ritual breach of oath.
They must also pay damages – their silence caused monetary loss.

title: Deposit denial (shevuat ha-pikadon)
vignette: Guardian denies having received a deposit and swears falsely, then admits.  Should he (a) repay principal + 20 % and a guilt-offering or (b) be liable only for principal?

options.text: Principal + fifth + offering – oath makes it aggravated theft.
Principal only – extra penalties apply only if the item is still intact.

title: Partners’ oath
vignette: Business partners dissolve; each suspects the other of skimming.  May the court impose mutual oaths before distribution?

options.text: Yes; reciprocal oaths clear suspicion.
No; oaths are burdensome unless a concrete claim exists.

title: Sharecroppers and produce division
vignette: Land-owner claims the tenant under-reported the crop yield.  Who swears – the owner (claimant) or the tenant (possessor)?

options.text: Tenant swears; he currently holds the goods.
Owner swears; burden is on the one demanding more.

title: Storekeeper vs. workers oath
vignette: Workers say they were not paid; storekeeper says he already paid them.  Should the workers swear and collect or the employer swear and go free?

options.text: Workers swear; presumption favours labourers’ wages.
Employer swears; money stays where it is until proof.

title: Administrator’s oath for orphans
vignette: Guardian of orphans claims expenses from the estate.  Must he swear to every withdrawal?

options.text: Yes; oath protects vulnerable heirs.
No; constant oaths deter honest caretakers.

title: Self-imposed abstention oath
vignette: A person swears, “I will eat no bread today,” then becomes faint.  Should he keep the oath at risk to health or break it?

options.text: Keep the oath; one’s word is binding despite discomfort.
Break it; preservation of life overrides self-imposed oath.

title: Single witness and oath
vignette: One witness supports a claim, not enough for collection.  Court offers defendant a choice: swear and go free or pay.  Is forcing an oath fair?

options.text: Yes; oath balances the witness’s partial proof.
No; burden of proof lies solely on claimant.

title: Over-oathing and sin
vignette: Community swears frequently over trivial matters.  Should leaders (a) tolerate to uphold honesty or (b) discourage to avoid habitual sinning?

options.text: Tolerate; oaths maintain truthfulness in commerce.
Discourage; needless oaths lead to transgression.

title: Rolled-in claims (gilgul shevuʿah)
vignette: A defendant is already obligated to swear on Claim A (partial admission).  The plaintiff tries to tack on Claim B, demanding the same oath cover both disputes.  Is that fair?

options.text: Allow one oath to cover every pending claim (gilgul); maximise efficiency and deter lying.
Limit the oath to the original claim; each additional claim needs its own proof.
